Sav., Mrs. Lily
Tinistino, 1931

1. What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1941.

2. Where did you go to homesteaders? SASKATCHEWAN.

3. How far from living before that? Approximately 100 miles.

4. How many people did you prepare meals? Usually cooked for myself.

5. How often could a visit be made by the storekeeper? Visited regularly.

6. What kind of crops did you usually buy? Fresh vegetables, apples, pears, plums.

7. What kind of flour did you use? Whole wheat flour.

8. Have you had any problems with the flour? No.

9. What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 10 cents.

10. How much did you use per month? 50 pounds.

11. Have you had any problems with the flour? No.

12. What other fruit products did you use? Applesauce.

13. Did you grind your own wheat? No.

14. Did you mind the work? Not at all.
1. PERSONAL HISTORY

What year did you start homesteading in North Dakota? 1941.

Where did you go to homesteading school? NDSU, NDSU, NDSU, NDSU (University of North Dakota).

For how many people did you replace metal? 5.

How far out is to your nearest store? 2 miles.

How often would you visit the store? Weekly.

What crops did you usually buy? Wheat, corn, oats, hay.

What animals did you usually keep? Cows, chickens, pigs.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

Have you used any flour mill locally? No.

Was the price for a bushel of flour $1.50?

What other grain products did you use? None.

Did you rent your own wheat for processing? No.

How did you grind it? By hand.

Did you have the whole grain? Yes.

Did you grind it yourself? Yes.

Did you have the flour milled locally? No.

Was the price for a bushel of flour $1.50?

What other grain products did you use? None.

Did you rent your own wheat for processing? No.

Did you have the whole grain? Yes.

Did you grind it yourself? Yes.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lb bag.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? No idea.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? (illegible)

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At what price? Don't know.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From one cow, gradually increasing as the herd grew.

Butter from same place. Eggs from 72 hens.

What was the price of butter? From 13 cents of eggs? 10-15-25 cents.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, hor. Lime water or just in an egg crate.

Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Cattle, Sheep, Prairie Chickens, Ducks, Rarely a Goose, Wild Turkey, Chicken.

How did you get fresh meat? Killed it.

How often did you get fresh meat? In fall, kill a cow for winter, spring use.

How did you preserve meat? Brined pigs.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? For a very short time.

If so what year was it organized? Too few families around to bother.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Ducks, Prairie Chicken.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? None.

An occasional bit of canned Salmon (25 cents).

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? In later years when Kinistino Village came into existence, 1/4 lb packaged, powdered cod could be procured, also dried fish.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) Slough & Rain Water. Dugout Not Known.

How far was this water from your home? 2 miles lake across one side & 3/4 mile on other side.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Pail & barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Buy, Neighbor made.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes. Wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Pea Cream, others.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Wood, from 20 to 30 miles South.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Coal came in after 1905. Some it miserable stuff.

The past 3 or 4 years Oil has been used by some.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Moore, Eastern Canada.

What year was it purchased? Don't know. Price? Don't know.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, kettles, iron pots for boiling, tin utensils.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware, enamel.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Bacon & Eggs
Meat of some kind with potatoes, other vegetables perhaps.
All the year. Milk Pudding, Suet puddings, Cakes
My husband Christopher Theodore Gay died 1923, age 59.
My Mother Mrs Grundy died 1916, age 82.
Myself.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? ......................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Served our first Christmas dinner in 1902.
Christmas 1901. My husband was threshing at a neighbour's (Charles Watson).
Present: Just ourselves.
Mince pie. Rum Pudding. Roast of Beef, Vegetables.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No! No! Fat & hefty.
No sickness, no doctors.
Lots of hard work.
Kept us sound, probably.

Bacon & Eggs
Meat & Gravy

Broccoli

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in 1902?

Christmas 1901. My husband was working at a neighboring farm (Charlie Affinton).

Present: Turkey, Ham, Bread, Vegetables.

19. Have you ever refused to almost starvation level living on two or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No! No! Fat & healthy.

No sickness, no doctor.

Lots of hard work.

Kept no records, probably.
